item.title: Markets Rally on Senate Deal; IBM and EBay Earnings Disappoint
item.dc:creator: InvestorGuide Staff
item.description:
On Wednesday the markets rallied after the Senate agreed to a deal that would reopen the government and raise the debt limit in the US. Votes will occur later in the day and Speaker Boehner made comments that the GOP will likely approve the proposal. If ratified by both houses of Congress, the government will

item.title: Budget Deal Hopes Push Markets Higher on Monday (NFLX, AAPL)
item.dc:creator: InvestorGuide Staff
item.description:
Several signals of progress in Washington pushed stocks higher on Monday. There are just three days before the US hits the debt ceiling and investors are betting that a deal will soon be reached. item.title: US Indices Extend Gains; Gold Falls to Three-Month Low
item.dc:creator: InvestorGuide Staff
item.description:
Stocks extended their large gains from yesterday on Friday as optimism grew for a potential debt deal in the US. item.title: House Proposes Debt Deal, Sending Stocks Higher on Thursday (BBY, AMZN)
item.dc:creator: InvestorGuide Staff
item.description:
House Republicans were able to propose a short-term solution to the budget standoff in Washington DC, sending the markets higher in what was the second-best day of trading this year. The plans involves a debt hike that will last for six weeks before a more permanent solution must be determined. Investor confidence rose while reports
Read the full article...

item.title: Markets Trim Losses; Obama Picks Yellen for Top Fed Job (CSCO, AA)
item.dc:creator: InvestorGuide Staff
item.description:
Stocks were finally able to end with slight gains on Wednesday as many hope for a short-term deal that will lift the debt ceiling. Federal Reserve vice chairwoman Janet Yellen was nominated as chairman Bernanke’s replacement, which would make her the first female leader. item.title: Obama Urges Boehner to Open Government; Techs Hit in Selloff
item.dc:creator: InvestorGuide Staff
item.description:
The S&P 500 reached a four-week low on Tuesday after most stocks continued to fall sharply. Few signs have emerged that the government shutdown, now on its second week, will end with a deal soon. President Obama made statements that he is happy to negotiate on everything besides a continued shutdown and debt ceiling hike.
Read the full article...

Read the rest of Obama Urges Boehner to Open Government; Techs Hit in Selloff at InvestorGuide.com.

item.title: Wall Street Ends Slightly Higher on Friday; Twitter Talks IPO
item.dc:creator: InvestorGuide Staff
item.description:
Indices were able to make slight gains on Friday but politicians in Washington appeared to make no progress in shutdown or debt ceiling debates. item.title: Stocks Continue to Retreat As Debt Crisis Threatens Global Economy
item.dc:creator: InvestorGuide Staff
item.description:
Growing anxiety over the US government shutdown caused the markets to retreat again on Thursday. By the end of the day losses were trimmed slightly after Speaker John Boehner stated he would not let a default on debt occur.
